thread.title: Oil Extends Losses On China Demand Concerns
thread.title_full: Oil Extends Losses On China Demand Concerns

author: RTTNews Staff Writer
title: Oil Extends Losses On China Demand Concerns
text: Oil held an overnight decline on Tuesday after economic readings from China showing falling refining activity and weak retail sales reinforced concerns about slowing demand in the world's top crude importer. China's top leaders have signaled stronger stimulus to help fill a hole in consumer demand in recent days but gave no details. Analysts say that Beijing will have to take radical action to stem deflation. Benchmark Brent crude futures were down half a percent at $73.57 a barrel in European trade, while WTI crude futures fell 1.2 percent to $69.89. Investors also remain worried about a global glut after predictions that the global oil market will return to surplus in 2025. The International Energy Agency (IEA) predicted a significant global oil surplus in 2025, despite OPEC+'s efforts to curb production. Meanwhile, the U.S. Federal Reserve is scheduled to announce its monetary policy on Wednesday, and a 25-bps rate cut is already priced in by markets. The updated policy statement and Fed Chair Jerome Powell's press conference may offer additional clues regarding future interest rates under the Trump administration. For comments and feedback contact: editorial@rttnews.com Market Analysis December 13, 2024 10:01 ET This week several major central banks announced their final interest rate decisions for this year. The main central banks included the European Central Bank, the Swiss National Bank and the Bank of Canada. Find out what they decided and the forward guidance they gave. Data headlines were dominated by the inflation figures out of the U.S. and the foreign trade data from China. Read RTT News stories to learn more about these events.
